Introduction

Acute appendicitis is characterized by inflammation of the appendix, a vestigial structure located at the base of the cecum (

figure 1
).  Patients typically present with abdominal pain, low-grade fever, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.  The abdominal pain characteristically begins in the periumbilical area, then localizes to the right lower quadrant (RLQ).  Physical examination often shows exquisite RLQ tenderness as well as rebound tenderness and guarding.  The diagnosis is usually suspected clinically and confirmed with imaging (eg, CT scan).  Appendectomy is the treatment of choice in most cases.

Anatomy



The appendix is a tubular structure attached to the base of the cecum.  The tip of the appendix can terminate in various anatomical locations, such as the pelvis or retrocecal area.  This is clinically significant because it can alter the typical location of pain, making appendicitis a potentially challenging diagnosis.

Pathogenesis



Acute appendicitis is most often initiated by obstruction of the appendiceal lumen, which may be caused by:



  • Fecaliths:  hardened mass of stool that lodges in the lumen
  • Lymphoid hyperplasia:  an overgrowth of appendiceal lymphoid tissue, most common in younger patients in the setting of infection
  • Parasites (in endemic areas):  Schistosomes, Strongyloides stercoralis
  • Tumors:  rarely, neoplasms (eg, carcinoid tumor) compress the appendix


Obstruction promotes bacterial overgrowth and causes appendiceal distension.  Increased intraluminal pressure decreases perfusion, resulting in ischemia and necrosis of the appendiceal wall.  Perforation with spillage of inflammatory fluid and bacterial contents into the peritoneal cavity can occur, leading to localized abscess formation or diffuse peritonitis.  Typical bacteria involved include colonic flora such as Escherichia coli, Bacteriodes fragilis, enterococci, and streptococci.

Pathology



  • Early stage:  mucosal inflammation and edema
  • Suppurative phase:  neutrophilic infiltration through all layers of the appendix
  • Gangrenous phase:  necrosis and gangrene due to compromised blood supply
  • Perforation:  can lead to localized abscess or diffuse peritonitis

Clinical presentation



Patients with acute appendicitis usually present within 24-48 hours of symptom onset.  Classic clinical signs include:



  • Fever, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting
  • Abdominal pain:  initially vague, diffuse pain in the periumbilical area that localizes to the RLQ over time.  Afferent pain fibers for the appendix and overlying visceral peritoneum initially produce dull, referred pain at the umbilicus.  As the appendix enlarges, irritation of the parietal peritoneum causes well-localized, severe somatic pain in the RLQ.
  • Rebound tenderness (increased pain with sudden release of pressure) and involuntary guarding (tensing of abdominal muscles during palpation), which also present when the parietal peritoneum is irritated
  • McBurney point tenderness (
    figure 2
    ):  maximal tenderness located two-thirds of the distance from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine


Depending on the location and orientation of the appendiceal tip, additional clinical findings may be detectable with the following provocative maneuvers (

):



  • Psoas sign:  pain with extension of the right hip; suggests an inflamed retrocecal appendix (which typically lies across the right psoas muscle) or an abscess adjacent to the psoas
  • Obturator sign:  pain on internal rotation of the right thigh; pain when stretching the obturator internus muscle because an inflamed pelvic appendix (or abscess) is overlying on this muscle
  • Rovsing sign:  pain in the RLQ upon palpation of the left lower quadrant; confirms localized right-sided peritoneal irritation

Atypical presentations



  • Pregnancy/postpartum (
    figure 3
    ):  The appendix undergoes cephalad displacement by the gravid uterus, which may cause pain in the right mid-to-upper quadrant (rather than the RLQ), with an absence of peritoneal signs (due to decreased contact with parietal peritoneum).  Obstetric symptoms, including uterine irritability and contractions (due to the proximity of the uterus to the inflamed appendix) may also occur.
  • Pelvic appendix:  Patients may have dysuria, frequency, and tenesmus with adnexal tenderness on pelvic or rectal examination.
  • Retrocecal appendix:  Patients may experience only dull aching pain, rather than localized RLQ pain, because there is no contact with the anterior parietal peritoneum.  Tenderness may be more apparent on rectal or pelvic examination.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is primarily clinical, but imaging (eg, CT scan of the abdomen, ultrasonography, MRI) is typically performed for confirmation.



The Alvarado score is a scoring system used to help assess the likelihood of acute appendicitis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Factors included in the score are RLQ tenderness (+2), leukocytosis (+2), leukocyte left shift (>75% neutrophils) (+1), elevated temperature >37.5 C (99.5 F) (+1), rebound tenderness (+1), migration of pain to the RLQ (+1), anorexia (+1), and nausea/vomiting (+1).  Scores â‰¥7 suggest a higher probability of appendicitis, and diagnostic imaging is recommended for scores â‰¥4.

Differential diagnosis

Gastrointestinal



  • Gastroenteritis:  A viral or bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal tract that causes diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes fever.  Abdominal pain is usually diffuse and crampy in nature, and diarrhea is typically present.  Patients may have a history of spoiled food exposure or sick contacts with similar symptoms.
  • Mesenteric lymphadenitis:  Inflammation of mesenteric lymph nodes (typically located in the right lower abdomen) causes RLQ abdominal pain.  It often follows a viral infection, particularly in children, and can be differentiated from appendicitis by the presence of enlarged lymph nodes on imaging without appendiceal inflammation.
  • Ileitis:  Inflammation of the ileum due to bacterial infection (eg, Yersinia) can present with RLQ pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting.  However, diarrhea is usually a prominent feature that may help distinguish ileitis from appendicitis.
  • Crohn disease:  This causes recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever.  An acute exacerbation, particularly involving the ileum, can present similar to appendicitis, but a history of similar symptoms, bloody stools, and perianal disease suggests Crohn disease.
  • Other diagnoses to consider include right-sided colitis, Meckel or cecal diverticulitis, cholecystitis, and small bowel obstruction.

Gynecologic



  • Ovarian cysts:  Rupture or torsion can mimic appendicitis with acute RLQ pain, nausea, vomiting, and exquisite tenderness on examination.  However, the onset of symptoms is typically more rapid and severe at onset than appendicitis.  Pelvic ultrasonography can confirm the diagnosis by revealing characteristic cystic structures with associated free fluid (rupture) or decreased blood flow (torsion).
  • Ectopic pregnancy:  Pregnancy outside the uterine cavity may cause RLQ or right adnexal pain, but a history of missed menstrual period and possibly new vaginal bleeding are typical.  A positive pregnancy test and adnexal mass on ultrasonography is diagnostic.
  • Mittelschmerz:  This refers to midâ€“menstrual cycle pelvic pain that is associated with follicular growth and ovulation.  Pain is unilateral but often mild and lasting hours to days.  Vomiting, fever, and peritoneal signs are not characteristic.
  • Other diagnoses to consider include pelvic inflammatory disease, tuboovarian abscess, endometriosis.

Urologic



  • Urolithiasis:  Stones in the urinary tract cause nausea, vomiting, and unilateral pain in the flank or lower abdomen.  Pain is usually severe, but peritoneal signs are absent.  Stones, ureteronephrosis (eg, swelling of the ureter), and/or hydronephrosis (eg, swelling of renal calyx) are typically visible on imaging.
  • Testicular torsion:  Twisting of the spermatic cord impairs blood flow to the testicle.  Symptoms include acute onset of severe testicular pain that may radiate to the lower abdomen, with nausea and vomiting.  Examination typically shows an absent cremasteric reflex and high-riding, transverse testis.  The absence of testicular blood flow on ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis.
  • Other diagnoses to consider include urinary tract infection and pyelonephritis.

Laboratory evaluation



There is no diagnostic laboratory test for acute appendicitis, but the following tests are typically obtained as part of the evaluation:



  • Complete blood count:  Most patients have leukocytosis with a left shift (increased neutrophils).  Higher white blood cell counts are associated with more complicated disease.
  • C-reactive protein:  This is an acute phase reactant that increases with infection or inflammation.  It is typically elevated in patients with acute appendicitis, and higher levels suggest increased severity (eg, necrosis).
  • Complete metabolic panel and lipase:  This is useful to help assess for alternative causes of abdominal pain and ensure normal electrolytes and renal function (in preparation for possible surgery).
  • Urinalysis:  Pyuria may be present in patients with appendicitis (likely due to the proximity of the right ureter to appendiceal inflammation).  Urinary tract infection should also be ruled out.
  • Pregnancy test:  This can be used to exclude ectopic pregnancy in women of childbearing age and helps dictate additional imaging studies.

Imaging



  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast (
    image 1
    ):  preferred study for evaluating suspected appendicitis in nonpregnant adults due to its high sensitivity and specificity.  Findings suggestive of acute appendicitis include an enlarged appendix, periappendiceal inflammation (eg, fat stranding), appendicoliths, and, possibly, abscess.
  • Ultrasonography:  first-line imaging in children and pregnant women (to limit radiation exposure).  A noncompressible, enlarged appendix (diameter >6mm) suggests acute appendicitis.
  • MRI:  used in pregnant women and children when ultrasonography is nondiagnostic.  MRI has a high sensitivity and specificity, but cost and time often make this imaging modality prohibitive.

Management



Management of acute appendicitis involves prompt evaluation and intervention to prevent complications such as perforation and peritonitis (

figure 4
).

Uncomplicated, nonperforated appendicitis



The treatment of uncomplicated, nonperforated appendicitis involves:



  • Laparoscopic appendectomy:  standard treatment for acute appendicitis, typically within 12 hours.  Laparoscopy improves infection rates, reduces postoperative pain, and is the recommended approach even for patients who are pregnant or have comorbid conditions (eg, obesity).
  • Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics:  coverage for aerobic gram-negative bacteria and anaerobic bacteria (eg, ceftriaxone and metronidazole)


Of note, several trials have studied antibiotic-based nonoperative management of patients with nonperforated appendicitis.  Although most patients avoided appendectomy when treated with antibiotics only, there was no reliable way to predict which patients would fail treatment and require rescue appendectomy.  In addition, at 5 years, 40%-50% of patients treated with antibiotics had a recurrence that required appendectomy.  Physicians and patients should engage in shared decision-making when considering pursuing antibiotic-based nonoperative management.

Perforated appendicitis with a contained abscess



Patients who have a perforated appendicitis with a contained appendiceal abscess can have a high complication rate from immediate surgery (due to the mass of inflamed, infected, friable tissue).  If they are otherwise clinically stable, these patients should be managed with:



  • Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics
  • Percutaneous abscess drainage
  • Interval appendectomy (usually 6-8 weeks later)

Perforated appendicitis with generalized peritonitis



Acute appendicitis complicated by perforation with generalized (rather than localized) peritonitis are at significant risk for sepsis and septic shock.  Immediate intervention includes:



  • Immediate appendectomy with thorough irrigation and drainage of the peritoneal cavity (if unstable, hemodynamic resuscitation prior to emergency surgery)
  • Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics for several days
  • Close postoperative monitoring for sepsis and shock

Prognosis



Patients with nonperforated, uncomplicated appendicitis typically have an excellent prognosis with prompt surgical intervention.  Delays in diagnosis and treatment can increase risk for perforation, abscess, peritonitis, sepsis, shock, and death.  In addition, appendiceal perforation in pregnant women increases the risk for spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and preterm delivery.



There is an increased incidence of appendiceal neoplasms in patients â‰¥40 who have complicated (eg, perforated) appendicitis.  Interval appendectomy is recommended for all patients over 40 with complicated appendicitis who are initially managed nonoperatively.

Summary



Acute appendicitis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
) is a common surgical emergency involving inflammation of the appendix, usually from luminal obstruction.  Typical symptoms include migratory abdominal pain that begins in the periumbilical area and localizes in the right lower quadrant with associated nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever.  Examination showing tenderness at the McBurney point is highly suggestive of appendicitis, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging.  Appendectomy is the definitive treatment in most cases.
